channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: South Korean Hospital Scrutinized in MERS Outbreak
item.description: A patient at the Samsung Medical Center became a “superspreader” of Middle East respiratory syndrome after a misdiagnosis, leaving him to wheeze and cough around the hospital.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Nearly half of all confirmed MERS cases in South Korea have been traced to the Samsung Medical Center in Seoul, regarded as the nation’s best hospital.

item.title: Memo From Europe: Teaching the Holocaust to Muslim Germans, or Not
item.description: A proposal in Bavaria requiring younger students to visit a former concentration camp or a center documenting Nazi crimes has prompted debate.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Visitors at the former concentration camp in Dachau, Germany. Relaying Jewish history to Muslims, or Islamic history to Jews, or cooperating on what might seem a straightforward project is always fraught.

item.title: U.S. Lags in Efforts to Rein In Omar al-Bashir of Sudan, Critics Say
item.description: If the U.S. once led a global campaign against the Sudanese leader charged with war crimes, they say, it appears to have run out of ideas for stopping him.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: President Omar al-Bashir of Sudan at an election campaign rally in North Darfur in April. He took power in a coup in 1989.

item.title: Hong Kong Lawmakers Begin Debate Over Election Plan
item.description: The security presence in and around the Legislative Council is high after heated protests over the plan, which would allow a direct vote for the next leader.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A pro-democracy lawmaker displayed signs in the Legislative Council on Wednesday, urging a "no" vote on the Beijing-backed plan for choosing Hong Kong's next leader.

item.title: Escaped Tiger in Tbilisi Killed Man Before Being Caught and Put Down
item.description: News reports of the mauling near the central square of the Georgian capital came after the zoo had said all of the missing lions and tigers had been found dead.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: North Korea Says It’s Facing Its Worst Drought in a Century
item.description: The Korean Central News Agency, a state agency, said that more than 30 percent of the country’s rice paddies were drying up.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Police at Chinese Train Station Kill Attacker Armed With Brick
item.description: The man, an ethnic Uighur, was wounded and died later at a hospital, the Xi’an Railway Police said in a microblog post.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Suspicious Swiss Bank Deals to Be Part of FIFA Investigation
item.description: The official leading the inquiry in Switzerland said about nine terabytes of data had been seized during a sweep of the Zurich offices of world soccer’s governing body.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN

item.title: Ireland Mourns 6 Victims of Berkeley Balcony Collapse
item.description: Flags were flown at half-staff and tributes were paid after the deaths during a party in California prompted outpourings of grief across the country.
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: College Student in Queens Is Charged With Conspiring to Support ISIS
item.description: Munther Omar Saleh, 20, a student living in Queens who was arrested Saturday, is accused of plotting to attack New York City on behalf of the Islamic State, the authorities say.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Lawmakers Begin Debate Over Election Plan
item.description: The security presence in and around the Legislative Council is high after heated protests over the plan, which would allow a direct vote for the next leader.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A pro-democracy lawmaker displayed signs in the Legislative Council on Wednesday, urging a "no" vote on the Beijing-backed plan for choosing Hong Kong's next leader.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chinese Nurse Resigns, Bidding Farewell to Her Florence Nightingale Dream
item.description: Yan Xiaobing describes the harsher side of hospital life in China, where nurses endure long hours and low pay but suffer especially from verbal and physical abuse from patients and their families.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW and VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: A nurse seen through a door as she talked with a patient at Beijing You'an Hospital.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: What You Need to Know About the Vote on Hong Kong’s Election Rules
item.description: Hong Kong lawmakers are to begin debating on Wednesday a Beijing-backed proposal to change how the city selects its top official. We offer a primer on the issues.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Pro-democracy demonstrators outside the Legislative Council in Hong Kong on Monday night.

item.title: Greek Exit Would Shake, but Most Likely Not Shatter, Eurozone
item.description: Many analysts believe that changes in the European financial system could contain the fallout if Greece defaults on its debt at the end of the month.
item.dc:creator: PETER EAVIS
item.media:description: The Greek finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, left, listened to Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras addressing Parliament on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing |: Hundreds of Journalists Exiled Globally, Report Says
item.description: Almost a quarter of journalists from Syria have been forced into exile since 2010, a leading press advocacy group said in a report released Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Suleyman Demirel, Former Prime Minister of Turkey, Dies at 90
item.description: Mr. Demirel served as premier seven times in a political career that stretched over nearly half a century.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN KINZER
item.media:description: Suleyman Demirel, president of Turkey at the time, and President Bill Clinton during a state visit in Ankara, Turkey, in 1999.

item.title: World Briefing: Bangladesh: Top Court Upholds Death Sentence for Islamist Politician
item.description: The leader, Ali Ahsan Mohammad Mojaheed, secretary general of the Jamaat-e-Islami party, was convicted of five charges, including murder, abduction and torture, in 2013.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Tunisia: Train Strikes Truck, Killing 18
item.description: A Tunisian passenger train smashed into a semitrailer truck racing to cross the tracks early Tuesday, killing 18 people as two cars derailed.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: President Highlights Work to Restore Full Ties With the U.S.
item.description: A recent meeting between Venezuelan and American officials had opened an important channel that could lead toward restoration of full diplomatic ties.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Suleyman Demirel, Former Prime Minister of Turkey, Dies at 90
item.description: Mr. Demirel served as premier seven times in a political career that stretched over nearly half a century.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Suleyman Demirel, shown in Ankara in 2007, dominated Turkey’s politics for decades.
